instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> braindead
threads.message: Hi Folks, have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in today. The board is superclean no liquid. All voltages are there, also <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>. The CPU has 1.05v, but what is missing is 1.8v <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_REG</SIGNAL>. I checked <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, it has on pin 18 0.73v, and on pin 20 and 22 1.96v not sure if that is what it should be? VIN and Enable (0.8v) are there. <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL> is present on <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> and so is the 5V line on pin 6 of <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> and 7320. I?m not sure how to go about testing what comes out of <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> but it looks like something is wrong here. All looks prestine though. Thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> braindead
threads.message: So is <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0, 1.05, or 1.8 on the big coils next to the CPU. Any sign of drop damage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> braindead
threads.message:
"VIN and Enable (0.8v) are there."
If you mean <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL>, 0.8V is not good.

Do you get 3V at pin 7/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> braindead
threads.message:
Hi John L7310 and L7320 have 0V, no signs of hard drops.
At <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> pin 1 <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> i get 0.78v
At pin 7 from <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> I get 2.5-2.6v swinging so seems not OK

I measure 2v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> which is not good, no short to ground though, i measure 0.522v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> braindead
threads.message: I traced it back to <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>, looks like some microscopic corrosion around the IC, will replace it and report back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> braindead
threads.message: Fixed, this is exactly why i love to pay for the forum, couldnt have figured this without you guys!!!! Learned something again, makes me wonder how many boards i disposed because I thought the CPU was shorted :rolleyes:
